DataElement.preferredName: Primary Tumor Dominant Histologic Subtype Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text term to identify the predominant histologic subtype for a primary tumor.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to a tumor's histologic subtype._Occurring first in time or sequence; original; of greatest rank or importance or value._Occurring first in time or sequence; original; of greatest rank or importance or value._Pertaining to the combined microscopic physical features of cells and their surrounding extracellular environment in tissues._Exercising influence or control._Pertaining to the combined microscopic physical features of cells and their surrounding extracellular environment in tissues.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Occurring first in time or sequence; original. (American Heritage Dictionary):(NEE-o-PLAY-zha) Abnormal and uncontrolled cell growth.

Concepts.definition: Occurring first in time or sequence; original; of greatest rank or importance or value.

A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: An embryonal neoplasm characterized by the presence of epithelial, mesenchymal, and blastema components. The vast majority of cases arise from the kidney. A small number of cases with morphologic features resembling Wilms tumor of the kidney have been reported arising from the ovary and the cervix._Pertaining to the combined microscopic physical features of cells and their surrounding extracellular environment in tissues._A group forming a type within a larger type._Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Cells that cover the surface of the body and line its cavities.

Concepts.definition: Any of the cells of the epithelium, which covers the body and lines its cavities and glands.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Connective tissue cells of an organ found in the loose connective tissue. These are most often associated with the uterine mucosa and the ovary as well as the hematopoietic system and elsewhere.: Exercising influence or control.: An embryonal neoplasm characterized by the presence of epithelial, mesenchymal, and blastema components. The vast majority of cases arise from the kidney. A small number of cases with morphologic features resembling Wilms tumor of the kidney have been reported arising from the ovary and the cervix.

Concepts.definition: Connective tissue cells found in the tissue stroma of any organ.

An embryonal neoplasm characterized by the presence of epithelial, mesenchymal, and blastema components. The vast majority of cases arise from the kidney. A small number of cases with morphologic features resembling Wilms tumor of the kidney have been reported arising from the ovary and the cervix.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Mixed; being composed of a combination of normal and tumor cells.: An embryonal neoplasm characterized by the presence of epithelial, mesenchymal, and blastema components. The vast majority of cases arise from the kidney. A small number of cases with morphologic features resembling Wilms tumor of the kidney have been reported arising from the ovary and the cervix.

Concepts.definition: Mixed; being composed of a combination of normal and tumor cells.

An embryonal neoplasm characterized by the presence of epithelial, mesenchymal, and blastema components. The vast majority of cases arise from the kidney. A small number of cases with morphologic features resembling Wilms tumor of the kidney have been reported arising from the ovary and the cervix.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An embryonic undifferentiated cell that can grow and differentiate into organs or body parts.

Concepts.definition: An embryonic undifferentiated cell that can grow and differentiate into organs or body parts.
